arguments.argument: Healthcare providers should not deny essential medical services.
Patients’ rights should take priority over provider beliefs.
It ensures access to abortion care regardless of location.
Medical professionals have a duty to provide comprehensive care.
Refusal can delay urgent treatment and endanger lives.
Public healthcare providers are obligated to serve all patients equally.
Abortion is a legal medical procedure in many regions.
Denying care contributes to inequality in reproductive rights.
Conscientious objection can lead to systemic discrimination.
Patients deserve care without moral judgment.
Healthcare workers should not be forced to act against their conscience.
Religious freedom and personal ethics must be respected.
Mandating abortion services could reduce the number of medical professionals.
Other providers can offer services if one opts out.
It may create moral distress and burnout in providers.
Consent in medicine applies to both patients and providers.
There are alternative facilities and systems for abortion access.
Forcing procedures can erode trust in the provider-patient relationship.
Medical ethics require respect for personal moral boundaries.
A pluralistic society must allow for conscientious objection in healthcare.
